summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus opposition memorandum to Ghislaine Maxwell's twelve pre-trial motions in her criminal case (S1 20 Cr. 330). It argues against motions to dismiss based on Jeffrey Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, suppression of evidence, perjury charges, severance, sufficiency of the indictment, and various disclosure requests. The document details the legal and factual basis for the charges and the government's investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with conspiracy, enticement and transportation of minors, and perjury related to Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse scheme.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier; alleged co-conspirator with Maxwell in a scheme to sexually abuse minors; subject of a 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with the Southern District of Florida.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this opposition memorandum.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who authorized the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Andrew Oosterbaan
persons.role: Chief, Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section
persons.context: Department of Justice official consulted by the Southern District of Florida during the Epstein investigation and plea discussions.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein who protested about complying with parts of the Non-Prosecution Agreement after its execution.

persons.name: Maria Villafaña
persons.context: Lead prosecutor for the Southern District of Florida on the Epstein case; negotiated the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Spokesman for Ghislaine Maxwell who made statements in 2014-2015 calling a victim's claims 'untrue' and 'obvious lies,' leading to a defamation lawsuit.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Founder of Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, the law firm that represented victim 'Jane Doe 1' in a civil defamation lawsuit against Maxwell.

persons.name: Peter Skinner
persons.context: Attorney at Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP who contacted the USAO-SDNY in 2016 to request a meeting about a potential case involving Epstein.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for victim 'Jane Doe 1' who participated in a February 2016 meeting with the USAO-SDNY.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Attorney for victim 'Jane Doe 1' who participated in a February 2016 meeting with the USAO-SDNY and had a follow-up call in May 2016.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge of the Southern District of New York who granted the government's application to modify a protective order in the civil case, allowing compliance with a grand jury subpoena to Boies Schiller.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied a similar government application to modify a protective order in a different civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein).

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Deceased district judge who originally oversaw the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil litigation and entered the protective order.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: District judge who later oversaw the Giuffre v. Maxwell case and ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's deposition transcripts.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who commented at a July 2019 press conference that the investigation was assisted by 'excellent investigative journalism.'

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Palm Beach Police Department Detective who investigated Epstein; deceased. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: Michael Casey
persons.context: Purported agent of Minor Victim-1; deceased. The defense claims his testimony about the victim's behavior would have been helpful.

persons.name: Bernard R. Siskin
persons.context: Expert who prepared an affidavit on jury selection statistics for the government in a related case, attached as Exhibit 12.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to recruit, groom, entice, and transport minor girls for sexual abuse by Epstein.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney for SDFL, authorized the NPA that Maxwell claims should immunize her. The government argues the NPA does not bind SDNY or protect Maxwell.
Boies's firm represented a victim (Jane Doe 1) in a civil defamation suit against Maxwell. The government subpoenaed the firm's files, which Maxwell seeks to suppress.
Starr was Epstein's defense attorney who negotiated and later protested aspects of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Villafaña was the lead prosecutor for the Southern District of Florida who negotiated the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.
Skinner, along with Edwards and Pottinger, met with an AUSA in February 2016 to present information about Epstein, urging an investigation.
Chief Judge McMahon ruled on the government's application to modify a protective order, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena for materials from Maxwell's civil case.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida enters into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein, immunizing him and certain named co-conspirators for specific federal crimes between 2001 and 2007.

events.title: Giuffre v. Maxwell Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Jane Doe 1 (Virginia Giuffre) files a civil defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Meeting between Victim Attorneys and USAO-SDNY
events.description: Attorneys Peter Skinner, Brad Edwards, and Stan Pottinger meet with an AUSA from the SDNY to present information about Jeffrey Epstein and urge an investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed by Boies Schiller attorneys in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Five (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed a second time by Boies Schiller attorneys. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Six (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: USAO-SDNY Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York formally opens an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and possible co-conspirators, prompted by Miami Herald reporting.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoenas Issued to Boies Schiller
events.description: The USAO-SDNY issues grand jury subpoenas to Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP for documents related to the Giuffre v. Maxwell and Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein civil cases.

events.title: Chief Judge McMahon Modifies Protective Order
events.description: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon grants the government's ex parte application, modifying the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell to allow Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury sitting in White Plains, Southern District of New York, returns a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with six counts related to Epstein's sexual abuse scheme.

events.title: Maxwell's April 2016 Deposition Unsealed
events.description: Following an order by Judge Preska and affirmation by the Second Circuit, Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript is publicly filed.

keyFacts: The government argues Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with the Southern District of Florida is irrelevant: it does not bind the SDNY, does not name or immunize Maxwell, and covers different crimes and time periods than those charged.

The indictment is timely under 18 U.S.C. § 3283, which provides an extended statute of limitations (through the life of the victim) for crimes 'involving the sexual or physical abuse of a child'; the 2003 amendment applies retroactively to conduct not yet time-barred.

The government obtained materials from Maxwell's civil depositions via a grand jury subpoena to Boies Schiller after Chief Judge McMahon modified the protective order; the government denies misleading the court or colluding with the law firm.

Maxwell's perjury counts (Five and Six) are based on allegedly false statements during her April and July 2016 depositions in the Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation case; the government contends the questions were not fundamentally ambiguous and the falsity and materiality are for the jury to decide.

The use of a grand jury sitting in White Plains was proper, especially during the pandemic when it was the only available grand jury; the defendant's fair cross-section challenge fails as the jury pool was drawn from a properly designated geographic area and shows minimal absolute disparity for Black and Hispanic populations.
